metadata.titleEn: Ground water level dataset in Hulugou sub-basin of Heihe River Basin  (2011)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview:            
This data set is the daily scale groundwater level data of Qilian station from November 1, 2011 to December 31, 2011. In October 2011, two groundwater monitoring wells were arranged in hulugou small watershed. Well 1 is located beside the general control hydrological section of hulugou watershed, with a depth of 12.8m and an aperture of 12cm. Well 2 is located in the east of the Delta, about 100m away from the river, with a depth of 14.7m and an aperture of 12cm.            2. Data content:            
U20hobo water level sensor is arranged in the groundwater well, which is mainly used to monitor the change of groundwater level and temperature in hulugou small watershed. The data content is the temperature and atmospheric pressure inside the hole, and the data is the daily scale data.            
3. Space time scope:            
Geographic coordinates of well 1: longitude: longitude: 99 ° 53 ′ E; latitude: 38 ° 16 ′ n; altitude: 2974m (near the hydrological section at the outlet of the basin).            Geographic coordinates of well 2: longitude: 99 ° 52 ′ E; latitude: 38 ° 15 ′ n; altitude: 3204.1m (east side of the East Branch of the delta).

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Verification.Question: Is the use of U20HOBO water level sensors adequate for monitoring groundwater level changes in small catchments?
Is the setup of multiple weather stations (AWS) effective for obtaining comprehensive observation data in mountainous regions?

Disjunctive.Question: Do studies in this field predominantly utilize data from automatic weather stations, manual field observations, or satellite data for monitoring environmental variables?
Disjunctive.Answer: automatic weather stations and manual field observations

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting precipitation data in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is the presence of biases and errors in precipitation observations due to the remoteness and sparse distribution of monitoring stations, which complicates accurate data collection.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a comprehensive data collection approach for studying cryospheric hydrology in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: A comprehensive approach involves deploying multiple AWS for long-term monitoring of meteorological variables, using snow depth sensors, conducting manual and automatic evapotranspiration measurements, and employing soil parameter data collection along with LST observations to assess hydrological processes in alpine catchments.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of the data collection methods used for monitoring underground water levels in the context of cryospheric hydrology?
Feature Specification.Answer: U20HOBO water level sensors, groundwater wells, monitor water level and temperature changes, cluster wells.

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes are essential for evaluating the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff in alpine regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation, effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow, changes in vegetation patterns on water balance, implementation of suitable distributed hydrological models that incorporate cryospheric hydrology

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics of meteorological variables are monitored to understand the hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation components, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, precipitation

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'groundwater monitoring' in the context of hydrological research in arid inland river basins?
Definition.Answer: Groundwater monitoring is crucial for understanding the water balance and hydrological processes in arid inland river basins. It involves the use of sensors such as U20HOBO water level sensors for measuring groundwater levels and temperature changes. This helps in evaluating the effects of climate and cryospheric changes on water resources.

Definition.Question: What are 'automatic microlysimeters' and how are they used in hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Automatic microlysimeters are devices used to measure evapotranspiration by weighing the amount of water loss from a known volume of soil. In hydrological data collection, they are installed in standard meteorological fields to provide long-term data on water vapor exchange between the land surface and the atmosphere, contributing to a better understanding of water cycle dynamics in alpine catchments.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying challenges can be inferred from the sparse observations and remoteness of the Hulu catchment area, and how might these affect data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges of sparse observations and remoteness in the Hulu catchment area suggest difficulties in obtaining comprehensive and accurate data. This can lead to significant biases and errors in precipitation observations, as mentioned under the challenges. These conditions necessitate the use of diverse and possibly innovative data collection methods, such as automatic weather stations, multiple sensor types, and manual observations to compensate for the lack of data in remote and difficult-to-access regions.

Interpretation.Question: How can the installation of various monitoring systems, such as AWS, microlysimeters, and EC systems, inform the understanding of cryospheric hydrology in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The installation of these monitoring systems allows for the long-term collection of vital meteorological and hydrological data, such as air temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and evapotranspiration. This comprehensive data collection approach can help address the scientific objective of understanding the hydrological processes in mountainous regions and evaluating the effects of cryospheric changes on water resources, as outlined under the research objective.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences arise from the lack of adequate observation data on the evaluation of cryospheric impacts in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of adequate observation data poses significant challenges in accurately assessing the impacts of cryospheric changes, leading to potential biases in understanding the hydrological processes and the severity of their consequences on water resources in alpine regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of establishing comprehensive observation systems for understanding cryospheric changes in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The scientific objective is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine hydrological processes and evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in arid regions. This involves determining the spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation, assessing cryospheric changes on streamflow, evaluating vegetation pattern changes on water balance and river runoff, and developing a suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to understand soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in alpine catchments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity is crucial for implementing hydrological models in alpine catchments. The models require detailed soil parameter data to accurately simulate water movement through soils, affecting water balance, river runoff, and the overall hydrological cycle in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of studying groundwater and stream water samples in assessing cryospheric hydrology?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Studying groundwater and stream water samples helps in understanding the isotopic composition and hydrological processes in cryospheric regions. This data is essential for evaluating the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow and assessing the water resources in arid regions, contributing to a better understanding of the hydrological cycle affected by cryospheric dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in setting up and calibrating sensors for monitoring groundwater levels and temperature in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection method involves installing U20HOBO water level sensors in groundwater monitoring wells to measure water levels and temperature changes. The wells are strategically placed, with precise depth and diameter specifications to ensure accurate monitoring of the groundwater in alpine regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is long-term meteorological data collected and utilized to understand cryospheric hydrology in alpine catchments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term meteorological data is collected using Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) that monitor variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation. These data are combined with manual observations to evaluate the effects of climate and cryosphere changes on hydrology.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to measure and analyze precipitation and its impact on river runoff in cryospheric regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Precipitation is measured using rain-weighing sensors and through intercomparison experiments using pit gauges and double reference intercomparison gauges. This data helps in analyzing the impact of precipitation on river runoff, especially in terms of how cryospheric changes alter water balance and river discharge in alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the monitoring of groundwater levels and temperature variations in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of U20HOBO water level sensors installed in groundwater monitoring wells enables the monitoring of groundwater levels and temperature variations in alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do the use of automatic weather stations (AWS) and manual observations enhance the quality and reliability of hydrological data collection?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic weather stations (AWS) provide long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and soil temperature, while manual observations serve as reference points to enhance the quality and reliability of the data collected.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be expectations for biases and errors in precipitation observations in remote and vulnerable regions?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding changes in remote and vulnerable regions such as alpine areas poses challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations, leading to significant biases and errors in precipitation observations.

Expectation.Question: Why would researchers expect to face challenges in obtaining comprehensive observation data about environmental factors in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers face challenges in obtaining comprehensive observation data due to inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the hydrological processes in mountainous regions be expected to require a suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation for a suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology arises from the need to assess the effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow and water resources in mountainous areas.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing the nuances of cryospheric hydrology and groundwater changes in vulnerable regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, including the use of AWS, manual observations, and various sensors, provide comprehensive data on meteorological variables, soil parameters, and groundwater sampling. However, challenges remain due to the remoteness of regions and sparse observations, which can lead to significant biases and errors, particularly in precipitation measurements.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the integration of multiple data collection techniques enhance the understanding of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating different data collection techniques, such as AWS, stream-gauging, microlysimeters, and cluster wells, allows for a more holistic understanding of hydrological processes by capturing diverse environmental factors. This approach can help in evaluating the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on water resources, offering a more robust framework for modeling and analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What potential improvements could be made to existing datasets to better address the impacts of cryospheric changes on water resources in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvements could include increasing the density of observation stations to reduce biases in precipitation data, enhancing the accuracy of snow and ice measurements, and expanding the temporal and spatial coverage of groundwater and surface water sampling. These enhancements would provide a more detailed and accurate representation of the impacts of cryospheric changes on water resources.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how researchers gather comprehensive and accurate environmental observation data in remote alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers use a combination of automatic weather stations (AWS), manual observations, and various sensors like infrared radiometers, sonic ranging sensors, and microlysimeters to gather data on meteorological variables, soil parameters, and snow depth. These methods help overcome the challenges of remoteness and sparse observations in alpine regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used for monitoring groundwater levels and temperature changes in small catchment areas, specifically focusing on the instrumentation and data collection techniques applied.
Request/Directive.Answer: Groundwater levels and temperature changes in small catchment areas are monitored using U20HOBO water level sensors installed in groundwater wells. These sensors provide daily scale data on internal temperatures and atmospheric pressure, allowing for precise monitoring of groundwater conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in obtaining accurate precipitation observations in remote and arid inland river basins, and suggest potential solutions or improvements in data collection techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: Accurate precipitation observations in remote and arid inland river basins face challenges due to remoteness and sparse observations, which lead to significant biases and errors. Solutions for improving data collection techniques include using a combination of automatic weather stations (AWS) and manual observations, implementing advanced precipitation measurement systems like rain-weighing sensors, and conducting intercomparison experiments to enhance accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and evaluate the methodologies used to study the effects of cryospheric changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources, particularly focusing on the integration of various environmental factors and observational data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies used to study the effects of cryospheric changes involve comprehensive observation and integration of environmental factors, including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, radiation, soil moisture, and precipitation. Long-term monitoring is achieved through AWS, stream-gauging stations, microlysimeters, and infrared radiometers. These methods allow researchers to evaluate the impacts of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on hydrological processes in mountainous areas.
